headline: . . . and Looking Up
lead_paragraph: If that were the whole chronology instead of a selec. tive segment, 1970 would have been a year uniquely dismal. But no period can be so characterized that saw the war in Vietnam, in spite of flare‐ups, slowly grinding toward a halt—undeclared, unofficial and uncertain, but nonetheless welcome. Nor could any year be considered wholly bad that saw calm, however dispirited, returning to the campuses and to the streets of American cities.

headline: 2d Decade of War Begins; Truce Broken by Clashes

headline: Letters to the Editor

headline: First Withdrawal of 1971

lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Jan. 1 (UPI)—Presi dent Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam in a speech to members of the diplomatic corps who came to bring him New Year's greetings, said he believed any peace agreement with the Vietcong would be worthless unless the Communist movement in South Vietnam was first rooted out and de stroyed.

headline: The Contentious 91st
lead_paragraph: Anger, cross‐purposes and diffuse leadership charac terized the closing weeks of the 91st Congress as they had for most of its two‐year life. A deeply divided and war‐weary nation has found its conflicts mirrored in its national legislature. Under the circumstances, what is surprising is not that there has been discord but that, notwithstanding it, so much has been accomplished.

headline: Businessmen Against the War

headline: Headliners
lead_paragraph: After 22 years in Congress and a meteoric flight across the political skies in 1968. Former economics professor Eugene J. McCarthy, 54, retired from the Senate last week .to work “from outside” for reforms of Congress and the political parties. Characteristically cryptic as to whether his reform plans might include running for President in 1972 or forming a new party, the Minnesota Democrat said there were three issues that could “motivate me to action”: the Vietnam war, the “militarization of American life,” and “the handling of the economy.” His fellow Senators, who did not always enjoy his caustic wit, were generous in their praise on his departure. “He's a fine man,” said Senator John Stennis of Mississippi, no political ally, “and I hope he has a further contribution to make to American life.”

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Jan. 3—Vietnam does not dominate our consciousness as it did. Weariness suppresses thought about any subject eventually, and we find reasons for wishing it away. author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: VIETCONG GIVE TERNS ON TRUCE WITH U.S.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Jan. 3 (UPI) — The Vietcong said today that they would agree to a cease‐fire with the United States if Washington “declares it will withdraw all its troops and the troops of other foreign countries” from South Vietnam.

headline: LOWENSTEIN URGES U.S. CURBS ON SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 3—Representative Allard K. Lowenstein said today that if the American dilemma in Viet nam was to end, the Adminis tration in Washington would have to impose strict conditions for aid on the leaders of South Vietnam.

headline: Pentagon Unit Finds Drugs ‘Military Problem’ in Asia
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3—Increasing drug abuse among American military personnel in Vietnam and elsewhere in the Far East has become a “military problem” for which the authorities have found no ef fective solution, according to a report by a task force of the Defense Department.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) —A former soldier in Lieut. William Calley's platoon was granted immunity from prose cution today, paving the way for his testimony when Lieu tenant Calley's murder trial, re sumes next week. The man, Paul D. Meadlo, previously had, refused to testify.

headline: Veteran Tells of Spying on Youth Group
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) —A former military undercover agent says he spied for nearly six months on a Colorado youth group and its leader because a lieutenant colonel feared they would turn soldiers against the Vietnam war.

headline: That our presence in Vietnam is unwise, absurd and wrong
lead_paragraph: American participation in the Indochina war can be opposed from three points of view: the absolute moral one that this kind of indiscriminate destruc tion of man and nature cannot be condoned on any ground; the deterministic one that this kind of war inevitably derives from a particular economic and po litical system Which must be changed in order to bring that war to an end and prevent new ones of a similar nature; and the pragmatic one that this particular war happens to he indefensible on moral, polit ical and military grounds. headline: An End to Violence?
lead_paragraph: This communication does not ac company a bombing or a specific ac tion. We want to express ourselves to the mass movement not as military leaders but as tribes at council. It has been nine months since the townhouse explosion. In that time, the future of our revolution has been changed deci sively. A growing illegal organization of young women and men can live and fight and love inside Babylon. The F.B.I. can't catch us; we've pierced their bullet‐proof shield. But the town‐ house forever destroyed our belief that armed struggle is the only real revo lutionary struggle. It is time for the movement to go out into the air, to organize, to risk calling rallies and demonstrations, to convince that mass actions against the war and in support of rebellions do make a difference. Only acting openly, denouncing Nixon, Agnew and Mitch ell, and sharing our numbers and wis dom together with young sisters and brothers will blow away the fear of the students at Kent State, the smack of the Lower East Side and the na tional silence after the bombings of North Vietnam.

headline: The Screen:'Last Valley' Recalls a Story of Survival
lead_paragraph: "The Last Valley" is a kind of historical movie, a type of adventure drama, a sort of epic, and something of a parable, and it winds up being a bit more boring than is absolutely necessary, considering the possibilities.Experiencing the movie is very much like riding in a big, handsome, old Rolls-Royce that keeps wandering from one side of the road to the other, slipping its gears, speeding up and then suddenly breaking — all because the driver doesn't know where he's going or how fast he wants to get there, although it's apparent he wants to travel in all of the style that money can buy.The driver is James Clavell, the novelist ("King Rat") and film writer-director ("To Sir, With Love"), who wrote, directed and produced this adaption of J. B. Pick's 1960 novel set against the background of the Thirty Years' War (1618-1648), which was almost an anthology of war.Beginning as a rebellion of Protestant German princes against the Catholic Habsburgs, it evolved, over the decades, into a series of see-saw battles, mixed alliances and desperate power plays involving France, England, Spain, Denmark and Sweden, in addition to Austria and the German states. By the time the Treaty of Westphalia was signed, most of Germany had been devastated and about the only thing that had been accomplished was the irrevocable end of the Holy Roman Empire, which was dead anyway."The Last Valley" is a rather dreamlike story of survival set in a magnificent valley protected from the outside world by high mountains. Into this valley comes Vogel (Omar Sharif), a one-time school teacher who has been on the run for years, followed shortly afterwards by a small, exhausted army led by the Captain (Michael Caine), whose men kill and burn and rape on reflex and have long since forgotten what they're fighting for.The Captain, using Vogel as a go-between, effects a truce with the people of the valley, pledging to protect them from invasion in return for food, shelter and women for the winter, at the end of which the Captain goes off to fight another battle and Vogel is evicted, to continue his wanderings. The people of the valley survive, simply by enduring.Like Bertolt Brecht in "Mother Courage," Mr. Clavell, I suspect, sees the incredible horrors of the Thirty Years' War as a metaphor for contemporary horrors, but he seems either incapable of—or uninterested in—developing a physical drama with any kind of intellectual substructure. Vogel, a pragmatic dreamer, and the Captain, a career soldier whose cynicism is not quite complete, talk quite a lot about war and religion but the quality of their dialogue would not embarrass the folks on "Gunsmoke." When, in the spring, the Captain departs to engage in yet another battle, the outcome of which will make no difference to anybody, all he can say is that he must go to the battle "because it's there."So much money was obviously spent on the lavish production—on scenery, costumes, occasional battles and extras—that I suspect Mr. Clavell thought he was making a statement about civilization, and perhaps even Vietnam, that would somehow work as an action melodrama. Although Mr. Clavell, as a writer, has nothing in common with Shaw, "The Last Valley" kept reminding me of Guy Hamilton's misguided attempts some years ago to turn "The Devil's Disciple" into a popcorn movie.It's difficult to judge Mr. Clavell's effect on his performers, except to remark that Mr. Sharif and Mr. Caine, who've never struck me as especially subtle actors, are quite good, while Per Oscarsson ("Hunger"), who is, I think, a great actor, seems to be acting up a storm in a dramatic vacuum. It may be, however, that in his make-up as a slightly mad Catholic priest he looks just a little too much like Charles Manson.One technical point: the film, which opened yesterday at the Rivoli and Juliet 2 Theaters, favors such slow lap dissolves that you will spend what seems like most of the movie seeing double images.
author: By Vincent Canby

headline: Television
lead_paragraph: THE tricky issue of men tioning marijuana on the air arose recently in connection with the television show made from film footage of Bob Hope's annual Christmas tour of overseas military bases, and Hope's own remarks about the show as broadcast, The version that finally reached the home screen gave view ers no indication that Hope's wisecracks about pot had evoked perhaps the heartiest laughter among the troops; nor did the pictures on the tube ever confirm what Hope freely told the press and, in deed, discussed earlier and openly with Johnny Carson on the “Tonight” show.
author: By Jack Gould
